Rarely used Windows Transactional NTFS (.Data: Windows Event ID 4663; Windows Event ID 4688
Rarely used Windows Transactional NTFS (.Action: Monitor Windows Event ID 4663 for suspicious file modifications within a transaction, particularly focusing on executable files. Correlate with recent process creation events (Event ID 4688). Search for patterns involving transactional file operations followed by process creation from the modified file path that is then rolled back, though direct TxF API call detection relies on specific monitoring tools or low-level ETW logging.

Suspicious sequence or combination of lo.Data: Windows Event ID 4688; Windows Event ID 4656; Windows Event ID 4657
Suspicious sequence or combination of lo.Action: Analyze sequences of Windows Event ID 4688 for unusual parent-child process relationships involving standard Windows executables being launched in atypical ways. Look for patterns potentially indicative of low-level process manipulation, correlating with Object Access events (Event ID 4656/4657) targeting processes or threads, although direct API call sequence detection is challenging with standard logs and often requires EDR or specific ETW tracing.

Write access attempts to executable file.Data: Windows Event ID 4663; Windows Event ID 4688
Write access attempts to executable file.Action: Monitor Windows Event ID 4663 (Object Accessed) filtered for write operations on executable file types (.exe, .dll). Correlate these events with recent process creation events (Windows Event ID 4688) where the executable path matches the accessed file object. Analyze timestamps to identify write activity occurring abnormally close to the time of process creation (e.g., within milliseconds). Establish baseline file access patterns for common executables and flag significant deviations using frequency analysis.

Outbound network connections initiated b.Data: Zeek conn.log; Windows Event ID 5156; Windows Event ID 4688
Outbound network connections initiated b.Action: Identify network connection events (Zeek conn.log, Windows Event ID 5156) where the initiating process name (correlated via Windows Event ID 4688) is a common system process (e.g., svchost.exe, explorer.exe) not usually expected to make external connections or connect to unusual internal hosts/ports. Establish a baseline of expected network activity for these processes using frequency analysis and clustering of destination IPs/ports. Flag connections to rare destinations or those with unusual traffic patterns (using descriptive statistics or time series analysis on byte counts).

Correlate with recent process creation events (Event ID 4688). Established processes (e.g., svchost.exe.Data: Windows Event ID 4688; Windows Event ID 5156; Windows Event ID 5157; Windows Event ID 4663; Zeek conn.log
Established processes (e.g., svchost.exe.Action: Profile typical network connections (Zeek conn.log, Event ID 5156/5157) and file access patterns (Event ID 4663) for common Windows processes (e.g., svchost.exe, explorer.exe) on different system types (servers/endpoints). Use statistical analysis (e.g., frequency analysis, clustering) to identify significant deviations from normal behavior (e.g., svchost.exe initiating outbound connections to rare IPs/ports, accessing unusual files) that could indicate process injection.
